Wednesday 6th 5 pm left for Houston - 8 pm crossed  Fort  Bar - Thursday 7th Got into Buffalo Bayou like to a canal - the bottom wooded principally with Pine - ? to sandy soil - fine Magnolias in flower  -  This is not the land for plantations- too poor - passed  the Field of St. Jacinto - ? is busy - 'A deserted Village' 
10 am arrived at Houston - San ? resident  -
Afternoon went to see Count de [?] & family 10 Miles out up the Bayou - found them in a most miserable plight - sulky & disgusted - The Count thought of establishing a plantation here &  then bringing someone in charge - [?] & comes here occasionally - these are too dry lands for Cotton & not wet enough for general farming & more particularly with lands of a Frenchman the future here was distressing utter [?] -

  He has only been some 30 miles West to the [?] & up to LaGrange - And has come to the conclusion that  "Texas is one bayou marsh - & some holes with  water in them "!  - Ridiculous - Wishes to accompany me to the West -

Friday 8th - Attended [?] Congress - The principal

Tuesday 12 - Daylight - Whilst retiring to Cypress B. A. is half way to Benzoria & his wells are 18 ft deep sand bottom (good water) indeed the sand commences at Surface - & with Prairie the Mould is very thin - Bayou Hones is Marked on the Maps Flues.  Deer pretty plentiful - and fine birds.  Very hot traveling - A covered Buggy is preferable to Horseback if traveling in day-time returned to Binghams to Sleep -
Sunday 10th.  8 am left for Houston arrived 1 PM.  Never had answer from Corpus Christi that there were some 700 Mexicans and two pieces of Artillery at San Setandes thus this if true the Volunteers will have some amusement - It may be only a marauding party -

  The people of the Northern States are not the arrant  X Emigrant lovers as those of the Western & Southern States of the Union.   Some Emigrants to get out of "difficulties" others knowing that the known SW lands are rich & [?] & Many try to persuade themselves that they are going to a land of "Milk & Honey" & this is literally true - for Stock raising is Easy - & Wild honey in abundance - then these new lands of Texas rarely require scraping & a crop of cotton & corn comes up easily the first year - in the majority of locations - clearly the land is not [?] for on the skirts of the "bottoms" of [?] - the Agriculturalists can produce immediately - either on the bottoms and in the woody country that extends from River to river there are open patches sufficiently large to form plantations and Farms.  Under the "Emperors" system and Since then & up to early 1842 Grants of land were given to Emigrants thus all that was wanted was to arrive in the case of a Planter with his Negros & in a short time the wilderness showed forth cotton crops, which crops found their way to N. The Farmers generally cultivate or "raise" cotton Enough for their own use - which the females of their families - card & spin for rough clothing - and the ? then make "first rate" particularly "hunting ? Coshattees, Indians probably as similarly of the Natchez - they worship the Sun & Moon  That a Woman of this tribe yesterday on  horseback - good looking and matronly - the chase - hair in one plait behind - cotton dress the Upper part kept together by a large Silver brooch -the principal parts of them live in a village below Swartwood [?] C. Chiefs visit to Galveston are a quiet orderly tribe & are ? by the settlers - grow Corn - Their Method of preparing deer skins is the following done by the women. The Men only hunt.  Soaked in water for a time, the hair scraped off - rubbed with the brains of deer and ? - those dried with Smoke of bark of trees These skins are of a tawny hue, soft and used principally for hunting dress - Some of the Indian tribes make very smart dresses -

  The Coshattes move about - the reason I presume is that the White man wishes to have their lands - but their principal villages are "Colete" that is the Lower [?] Village - near Swartwood there is another Coshatte Village & above this another called "Battist"
